title: record basic provenance (datalad version, git, etc) alongside with a commit
body:
#### What is the problem?

Troubleshooting some incorrect behavior of datalad discovered post-fact, might be tricky if used datalad (and its dependencies) version is not known.  I thought we had already an issue desiring such a record but I [failed to find it](https://github.com/datalad/datalad/search?q=datalad+version+commit+message&state=open&type=Issues)

I think it might be quite valuable to add a basic provenance record to the commit message (or may be some git notes?) with pretty much output of `datalad wtf -S datalad -S extensions -S git-annex -S python -S system` (or may be even full `wtf`).  

I think this might be actually good use case for git notes if we do both:
- record only datalad version in commit message with a brief "By: datalad <version>" 
- record `wtf` output in the machine readable (yaml) in a dedicated git note (datalad-provenance) which would be stored locally and could be interrogated later if needed.
